text: And unto Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg; for in his days was the earth divided; and his brother's name was Joktan.
text_kjv: And unto Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg; for in his days was the earth divided; and his brother's name was Joktan.
text_niv: Two sons were born to Eber:One was named Peleg, because in his time the earth was divided; his brother was named Joktan.
text_esv: To Eber were born two sons: the name of the one was Peleg,  for in his days the earth was divided, and his brother's name was Joktan.
text_nlt: Eber had two sons. The first was named Peleg (which means “division”), for during his lifetime the people of the world were divided into different language groups. His brother’s name was Joktan.
text_msg: Eber had two sons, Peleg (so named because in his days the human race divided) and Joktan.
text_nasb: Two sons were born to Eber; the name of the one [was] Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided; and his brother's name [was] Joktan.
context: Genesis 10, often called the Table of Nations, outlines the descendants of Noah’s sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, tracing the origins of the diverse peoples and nations of the ancient world. This chapter provides a framework for understanding the ethnic and linguistic distribution following the Flood. Eber, mentioned in verse 25, is significant as he is a descendant of Shem, and the name 'Hebrew' is believed to be derived from his name, marking him as an important ancestor of the Israelites. The genealogy in Genesis 10 is not merely a list of names; it is a theological statement about the ordering of the post-Flood world according to God's plan. The division of the earth in Peleg's time is a pivotal event, hinting at a significant geographical and possibly linguistic shift that shaped the subsequent history of humanity. It's crucial to note that the specific nature of this division is debated, with interpretations ranging from literal continental drift to a more symbolic representation of the scattering of peoples after the Tower of Babel, which is detailed in Genesis 11. Understanding the context of Genesis 10 within the broader narrative of Genesis allows us to appreciate the significance of verse 25 as a marker of a crucial turning point in the story of humanity's dispersal and the beginning of distinct cultural and linguistic groups. Furthermore, the placement of Eber and his lineage within Shem’s line underscores the importance of this lineage to the unfolding narrative of God's covenant and promise.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 10:25 carries substantial weight. The birth of Peleg, whose name means “division,” signifies a pivotal moment in salvation history. The phrase “in his days was the earth divided” is interpreted in various ways. Some scholars propose a literal geological event causing continental separation. Others suggest a more figurative division, potentially linked to the Tower of Babel narrative in Genesis 11, where humanity's unified language was confused, leading to their dispersion across the earth. Regardless of the precise nature of the division, theologically, it points to the consequences of human sin and rebellion against God's plan. While God commanded humanity to fill the earth (Genesis 1:28), their concentration in one place and attempt to build a tower to reach heaven (Genesis 11) represented defiance. Therefore, the division can be seen as an act of divine judgment, scattering humanity and preventing them from consolidating power against God. Furthermore, the verse highlights God's sovereignty over history. Even in the division and scattering, God's purposes are not thwarted. He continues to work through different nations and peoples, ultimately leading to the fulfillment of His promise of redemption through Abraham’s descendants. The inclusion of Joktan, Peleg's brother, serves to emphasize the branching of the Semitic lineage and foreshadows the diversity of cultures and peoples that will emerge from Eber’s line. This verse, therefore, stands as a testament to both God's judgment and His enduring faithfulness in guiding the course of human history toward His redemptive purposes.
application: Genesis 10:25, though seemingly a simple historical statement, offers profound practical implications for our modern lives. Recognizing that humanity was divided “in his days” underscores the reality of diversity and difference in our world. It challenges us to move beyond superficial understandings of culture and ethnicity and to delve into the richness and complexity of human experience. In a world often marked by division and conflict, this verse calls us to cultivate empathy and understanding toward those who are different from us. The verse also reminds us that division, even though sometimes arising from human failings, is not necessarily permanent. The Tower of Babel narrative tells us that division comes as a consequence of pride and human arrogance. We must strive to overcome these tendencies in our own lives, in our communities, and in our relationships with others. Practically, this means actively seeking to bridge divides, listening to different perspectives, and working towards reconciliation. This also means to resist the urge to conform to the world's standards and ways of doing things, and instead to align ourselves with God's will. Furthermore, the understanding that God is sovereign over all nations (Acts 17:26) calls us to engage with the world missionally. We are called to witness to Jesus Christ in every nation, every culture, and every tribe, working toward the ultimate reconciliation of all things in Christ. Ultimately, this verse is a call to embrace our shared humanity, to recognize our common origin in Noah, and to strive for unity in Christ, even amidst the diversity that marks our world. We are to be peacemakers, building bridges rather than walls, and striving to fulfill the Great Commission.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the Table of Nations and the glimpse it gives us into the origins of the peoples of the world. We acknowledge that in Peleg's day, the earth was divided, and we see the echoes of that division in our world today. Forgive us for the times we have contributed to division, whether through pride, prejudice, or misunderstanding. Grant us a spirit of humility, empathy, and love for all people, regardless of their background or beliefs. Help us to see the beauty and richness in diversity, and to work towards reconciliation and unity in our communities and in the world. Lord, use us to be instruments of your peace, building bridges and breaking down walls. Empower us to share the gospel with all nations, so that all people may come to know you and experience the fullness of life in Christ. May your kingdom come, and your will be done, on earth as it is in heaven. Amen.

faqs.answer: Peleg's name, meaning 'division,' is directly connected to the statement that 'in his days was the earth divided.' This suggests a significant event occurred during his lifetime that resulted in a separation or division of some kind. It highlights the importance of this period in the post-Flood world.
faqs.question: Q1: What is the significance of Peleg's name?

faqs.answer: Interpretations vary, ranging from a literal continental division due to tectonic activity to a more figurative division associated with the Tower of Babel incident and the subsequent scattering of humanity. Both literal and symbolic interpretations are possible.
faqs.question: Q2: What are the different interpretations of 'the earth was divided'?

faqs.answer: Many scholars believe Genesis 10:25 is directly connected to the Tower of Babel account in Genesis 11. The division mentioned in verse 25 is seen as the result of God scattering the people after they attempted to build a tower to reach heaven.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse connect to the Tower of Babel story?

faqs.answer: This verse highlights God's sovereignty because even though humanity's actions led to division, God was still in control. He used the scattering of the people to fulfill His command to fill the earth.
faqs.question: Q4: What does this verse tell us about God's sovereignty?

faqs.answer: Genesis 10:25, and the subsequent scattering of humanity, directly relates to the concept of mission. If the earth was filled with many different nations, each group needs to hear and have access to the message of salvation through Christ.
